claim.text: Amsterdam's canal houses, built on plots typically 5 to 7 meters wide (16 to 23 feet)
claim.claim: Amsterdam canal houses were built on plots typically 5 to 7 meters wide

results.summary: Amsterdam canal houses were historically built on narrow plots typically 5-7 meters wide due to taxation based on frontage width.
results.detail: This is well-documented in architectural history. Amsterdam's canal houses were built on narrow, deep plots because property taxes were levied based on street frontage. The standard plot width of approximately 5-7 meters (roughly 16-23 feet) is widely cited in architectural and historical literature about Amsterdam's canal ring (Grachtengordel). The narrow frontages led to the characteristic steep staircases and hoisting beams still visible today.
sources: Historical architectural documentation of Amsterdam's Grachtengordel (UNESCO World Heritage documentation)
General knowledge of Dutch urban planning history

claim.text: Charleston's single houses — one room wide, oriented with the narrow end to the street — fit on lots as slim as 25 feet
claim.claim: Charleston single houses fit on lots as narrow as 25 feet

results.summary: Charleston single houses are indeed designed for narrow lots and oriented with the narrow end facing the street, with lot widths commonly cited as 25 feet or narrower.
results.detail: The Charleston single house is a well-documented historic architectural form unique to Charleston, South Carolina. These houses are characteristically one room wide, with the narrow gable end facing the street, and feature a side piazza (porch). This design was specifically developed to accommodate the narrow urban lots of colonial Charleston, with 25-foot lot widths being a commonly referenced dimension in architectural literature. The orientation maximizes cross-ventilation and provides privacy via the side piazza entrance.

claim.text: The Strong Towns organization has documented how these 'fine-grained' streetscapes generate more tax revenue per acre than suburban development
claim.claim: Strong Towns organization documented that fine-grained streetscapes generate more tax revenue per acre than suburban development

results.summary: Strong Towns has extensively documented that traditional, fine-grained mixed-use development generates significantly more tax revenue per acre than suburban sprawl development.
results.detail: Strong Towns, founded by Charles Marohn, has published numerous analyses comparing tax productivity per acre across different development patterns. Their methodology measures property tax and sales tax revenue divided by land area, consistently showing that traditional downtowns and walkable neighborhoods outperform big-box retail and suburban residential development, often by factors of 10x or more. This has been documented across multiple cities including Lafayette, Louisiana; Spokane, Washington; and many others through their 'Value Per Acre' analysis framework.
sources: strongtowns.org - multiple articles on value per acre analysis
Escaping the Housing Trap by Charles Marohn and Daniel Herriges (2024)
Strong Towns: A Bottom-Up Revolution to Rebuild American Prosperity by Charles Marohn (2019)

claim.text: Houston's 2013 small-lot ordinance allowed single-family homes on lots as narrow as 1,400 square feet, roughly 25 by 56 feet
claim.claim: Houston passed a small-lot ordinance in 2013 allowing homes on lots as small as 1,400 square feet

results.summary: Houston did pass small-lot regulations, but the claim contains inaccuracies about the year and lot size specifications.
results.detail: Houston has passed multiple iterations of lot size regulations. The city reduced minimum lot sizes to 1,400 square feet in certain areas, but the key reform often cited is from 1998-1999, not 2013. There were subsequent modifications in later years. The 1,400 square foot figure appears in Houston's regulations, but the 2013 date may be conflating different ordinance amendments. Additionally, the claim describes 1,400 square feet as a lot 'width' measurement ('as narrow as'), but 1,400 square feet is an area measurement, not width.

claim.text: Alexander captured part of this in Pattern 109, Long Thin House
claim.claim: Christopher Alexander's Pattern 109 is titled 'Long Thin House'

results.summary: Pattern 109 in Christopher Alexander's 'A Pattern Language' (1977) is indeed titled 'Long Thin House'.
results.detail: This claim references a well-documented architectural pattern from Christopher Alexander's seminal work 'A Pattern Language: Towns, Buildings, Construction' (Oxford University Press, 1977). The book contains 253 patterns numbered sequentially, and Pattern 109 is 'Long Thin House', which addresses the principle that buildings should be narrow enough for natural light and ventilation to reach all rooms. This has been previously verified in the project's own quality gate report.
sources: Christopher Alexander, Sara Ishikawa, Murray Silverstein. A Pattern Language: Towns, Buildings, Construction. Oxford University Press, 1977

claim.claim: Jan Gehl conducted research in Copenhagen finding pedestrians walk faster and look less at façades when buildings exceed 15 meters in width
